The fast neutron $( E _ { n } > 1 \mathrm { M e V } )$ fluence calculated for this region is $0 . 7 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 2 }$ neutrons $\mathrm { c m } ^ { 2 }$ [7,8].

evidence_span: The corrosion reaction between the zirconium and the heavy water releases deuterium (D), part of which is incorporated into the metal. In this way, the total equivalent hydrogen isotope concentration in wppm is given by $[ \mathrm { H } ] _ { \mathrm { e q } } = [ \mathrm { H } ] + 1 / 2 ^ { \ast } [ \mathrm { D } ]$ , where [H] is the hydrogen content of the original material (about $1 5 { \pm } 5 \mathrm { w p p m } ,$ and [D] is the deuterium content incorporated in service.

source_id: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_013_chunk16
evidence_span: The error for the concentration range of the samples is 4 wppm. Considering the uncertainty in the original material content we add to this value 5 wppm and, from the statistical error obtained in batches of similar hydrogen contents, another 6 wppm. Then, we estimate for $[ \mathrm { H } ] _ { \mathrm { e q } }$ a global error of 15 wppm.
